conclusion: Two particles, A and B, start from rest at the same point and move in the same direction. A velocity-time graph is provided.
The graph shows velocities in terms of v0 and time in terms of t0.
The area under the curve for each particle represents the displacement from the starting point at any given time.
Particle A accelerates to 2v0 at t0, decelerates to zero by 2t0, and accelerates again to 2v0 at 3t0, then decreases to zero by 4t0.
Particle B increases steadily to v0 by 3t0, holds steady until 5t0, then decreases to zero by 6t0.
Positions at any time t can be represented by the area under their respective velocity curves.
The distance between them at any time t is the difference in the areas under their velocity curves.
To find when they are farthest apart, find when the difference in areas is maximized.
Particle A accelerates quickly and then decreases, while particle B starts slowly and reaches a steady velocity later.
Initially, particle A moves faster, so it will be ahead of particle B. As time progresses, particle B starts catching up.
Find the time t where the area under curve A minus the area under curve B is maximized.
Express positions of both particles as functions of time and find the difference to maximize.
Alternatively, calculate the area for each particle up to time t and find the difference.
For particle A, from t=0 to t=t0: velocity function is v(t) = (2v0/t0) * t.
From t=t0 to t=2t0: velocity function is v(t) = - (2v0/t0) * t + 4v0/t0.
From t=2t0 to t=3t0: velocity function is v(t) = (2v0/t0) * (t - 2t0).
Beyond t=3t0, velocity decreases to zero by t=4t0, and stays at zero.
Particle A's velocity peaks at 2v0 at t0, drops to zero at 2t0, rises to 2v0 at 3t0, and drops to zero at 4t0.
Particle B starts from zero, increases linearly to v0 at 3t0, holds steady at v0.
